com.twitter.elephantbird.pig.load
Class LzoBaseLoadFunc

java.lang.Object
  org.apache.pig.builtin.Utf8StorageConverter
      com.twitter.elephantbird.pig.load.LzoBaseLoadFunc
All Implemented Interfaces:
org.apache.pig.LoadFunc, org.apache.pig.SamplableLoader, org.apache.pig.Slicer
Direct Known Subclasses:
LzoBaseRegexLoader, LzoJsonLoader, LzoProtobufB64LinePigLoader, LzoProtobufBlockPigLoader, LzoTextLoader, LzoTokenizedLoader, LzoW3CLogLoader
public abstract class LzoBaseLoadFunc
extends org.apache.pig.builtin.Utf8StorageConverter
implements org.apache.pig.LoadFunc, org.apache.pig.Slicer, org.apache.pig.SamplableLoader

This class handles LZO-decoding and slicing input LZO files. It expects the filenames to end in .lzo, otherwise it assumes they are not compressed and skips them. TODO: Improve the logic to accept a mixture of lzo and non-lzo files.

setBeginsAtHeader

public void setBeginsAtHeader(boolean beginsAtHeader)
Set whether this chunk begins at the beginning of the entire file, just after the LZO file header.

Parameters:
beginsAtHeader - whether this is the first chunk of the file, and so begins at the LZO file header offset.

slice

public org.apache.pig.Slice[] slice(org.apache.pig.backend.datastorage.DataStorage store,
                                    java.lang.String location)
                             throws java.io.IOException
The important part of the loader -- given a storage object and a location to load, actually compute the splits. Walks through each LZO file under the given path and attempts to use the .lzo.index file to slice it.

Specified by:
slice in interface org.apache.pig.Slicer
Parameters:
store - the data storage object.
location - the given location to load, e.g. '/tables/statuses/20090815.lzo' when invoked as a = LOAD '/tables/statuses/20090815.lzo' USING ... AS ...;
Throws:
java.io.IOException

              throws java.io.IOException
Nothing to do here, since location can be an unexpanded glob. Also, the idea that validate returns void and instead throws an exception to fail validation is ridiculous.

                   org.apache.pig.impl.io.BufferedPositionedInputStream is,

Called on the datanodes during the data loading process, this connects a Map job with an input split.

bindTo in interface org.apache.pig.LoadFunc
Parameters:

end - the end offset of the input split.

skipToNextSyncPoint

public abstract void skipToNextSyncPoint(boolean atFirstRecord)
                                  throws java.io.IOException
Override to do any special syncing for moving to the right point of a new input split.

Parameters:
atFirstRecord - whether or not this is the first record in the file. Typically for line-based readers, for example, we want to skip to the next new line at the beginning of an input split because the arbitrary byte offset we're at generally puts us in the middle of a line. We count on the previous input split to read slightly beyond its offset to the end of the next line to account for this. However, this doesn't hold for the very first record in the file.
Throws:
java.io.IOException

setLoaderSpec

Set the loader spec so any arguments given in the script are tracked, to be reinstantiated by the mappers.

Parameters:
clazz - the class of the load function to use.
args - an array of strings that are fed to the class's constructor.

incrCounter

protected void incrCounter(java.lang.String group,
                           java.lang.String counter,
                           long incr)
A convenience function for working with Hadoop counter objects from load functions. The Hadoop reporter object isn't always set up at first, so this class provides brief buffering to ensure that counters are always recorded.

incrCounter

protected void incrCounter(java.lang.Enum<?> key,
                           long incr)
A convenience function for working with Hadoop counter objects from load functions. The Hadoop reporter object isn't always set up at first, so this class provides brief buffering to ensure that counters are always recorded.

verifyStream

protected boolean verifyStream()
                        throws java.io.IOException
Called to verify that the stream is readable, i.e. not null and not past the byte offset of the next split.

Returns:
true if the input stream is valid and has not yet read past the last byte of the current split.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
